STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
April 11, 2023
Debra Ann Matthews
Children’s Center Wayne Co
79 W Alexandrine St.
DETROIT, MI, 48201-2015
RE: License#: CB820201055
Dear Ms. Matthews:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on . Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is
required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 248-860-0787.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-3317
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB820201055
Licensee Group Organization: Childrens Center Wayne County
Licensee Designee: Carlynn DENISE Nichols
Chief Administrator: Debra Ann Matthews
Name of Agency: CHILDREN'S CENTER WAYNE CO
Agency Address: 79 W ALEXANDRINE ST
DETROIT, MI 48201-2015
Agency Telephone #: 3138315520
Original Issuance Date: 08/01/1992
Service Types: Place children for adoption, Certify foster
homes for license, Supervise Independent
Living, Place children in foster home,
Evaluate Applicants for adoption

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION
A. Consultant
Date(s) of On-site Inspection: 03/22/2023, 3/23/2023, & 3/27/2023-3/30/2023
Total No. Of No. of
Records
Reviewed
Current licensed foster homes 60 3
Homes pending licensure 8 3
Foster homes closed since the last inspection 12 3
Foster homes borrowed since the last inspection 1 1
Special Investigations in foster homes since last inspection 21 4
Incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect
in foster care since last inspection 1 1
Incidents of substantiated corporal punishment in foster care
since last inspection 1 1
Children receiving direct foster care case management (placement in foster homes,
relative homes, CCI, hospital, etc.) 62 4
Children discharged from care during this period 12 3
Youth in independent living placement 55 6
Youth discharged from an independent living placement
since the last inspection 37 6
Applicants approved for adoption since the last inspection 11 4
Applicants denied for adoption since the last inspection N/A N/A
Closed child adoption cases since the last inspection 16 4
Open child adoption cases 17 3
Current employees who have worked at the facility for:
More than a year 33 6
Less than a year 6 6
Persons Interviewed:
Licensing Staff 1
Foster Care Staff 1
Adoption Staff 1
Supervisory Staff 3
Administrative Staff 4

B. Analyst
Total No. No. Visited
Licensed foster homes 60 3
Unlicensed relative homes 24 3
Number of persons interviewed:
Foster Parents 3
Foster Children 9
Relatives 3
Others (identify person interviewed by role) N/A
III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(3) An agency shall complete a special evaluation within
45 calendar days after receipt of the information. If
additional time is required, then the agency shall inform
the foster parent, in writing, of the basis for the extension
and the expected length of the extension. The total time
for the completion of the special evaluation shall not
exceed 90 calendar days without written approval from
the chief administrator or is or her designee.
One of four special evaluations reviewed did not show
documentation of approval by the chief administrator and
or designee for a special evaluation that extended beyond
the 90-day time frame.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation,
an agency shall complete a written report.
In one of four special evaluations reviewed the written
report was not completed within 15 days of the
evaluation's 11/21/2022 conclusion. The written report
was completed 3/21/2023.

CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency’s medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(f) The provision of a dental examination and any
treatment required for each child who is 4 years of age
and older, including both of the following:
(i) A dental examination within 12 months before
placement or a new dental examination shall be
completed not more than 90 calendar days after
placement.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed showed
the child’s dental examination, due by 11/28/2022 was
completed late on 1/19/2023.
Repeat Violation Interim 2022.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(3) When case responsibility changes from 1 child placing
agency to another child placing agency, a modified
service plan must be completed within 30 calendar days
of the change in responsibility if no other plan is done
within 30 days. The plan shall address why the agency
responsibility changed and whether there are any
modifications to the existing service plans.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed did not
show documentation of a 30-day report due by 2/16/2023,
per the child's 1/17/2023 placement with the agency.
CPA Rule 400.12420 Updated service plan.
(1) An updated service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(b), shall include all of the following
information:
(g) A child management plan which includes any
changes made since the previous plan and which is to
be used by the foster parents.
In seven of 13 updated service plans reviewed
(pertaining to three of eight open foster child records) the
service plan did not contain the specific behavior
management plan to be used by the caregiver.
CPA Rule 400.12511 Termination.

(1) When an agency terminates its independent living
services for a youth, the agency shall document all of the
following in the case record within 30 calendar day of the
termination of its services:
(c) A summary of the services provided during care and
the need that remain to be met.
(d) Provision for any follow-up services.
Two of six closed independent living youth records
reviewed did not show documentation of (c), and (d) as
required by the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12511 Termination.
An agency shall ensure and document that each youth
who ends independent living is provided with all of the
following.
(a) Basic information about health, housing,
counseling/mental health services, and emergency
resources.
(b) A birth certificate.
(c) A social security card.
(d) The youth’s funds and personal property.
One of six closed independent living youth records
reviewed did not show documentation of (a)-(d) as
required by the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12607 Agency recommendation.
(4) An agency shall provide the applicants for
adoption with a signed and dated copy of the evaluation
and recommendation upon its completion.
One of four adoptive family records reviewed showed the
family was not provided a copy of its evaluation(s) timely
as described by the rule.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2022.

n seven of 13 updated service plans reviewed (pertaining to three of eight open foster
child records) the service plan did not contain the specific behavior management plan to
use by the caregiver.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Nothing this inspection.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
ADM 330 Quarterly Progress Report:
• The agency was advised including the dates of its home visits with the child
and caregiver within the narrative section of the quarterly progress report may
aid it in showing all required contacts, especially when there are delays
related to the case being assigned to them in MISACWIS.
2). Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance will all additional MISEP requirements except for the following:
None this inspection.
3. Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MDHHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional MDHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional MDHHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
SRM 103 Staff Qualifications and Training: In Service Training-
Supervisors and Staff.
MDHHS and private caseload-carrying staff and
specialized support staff must complete 32 hours of in-
service training each calendar year.
Only 15.75 hours were documented for one of the
agency’s 11 foster care workers for the calendar year
2022. The agency acknowledged the worker had not
completed the required 32 training hours.
ADM 300 Child adoption assessment.
Addendum:
The DHS-606, Child Adoption Assessment Addendum,
must be used to update the DHS-1927, Child Adoption
Assessment, on an annual basis if the child has not been
placed for adoption. The DHS-606, Child Adoption
Assessment Addendum must also be completed when

there is a change in placement or other significant event
for the child.
One of five open child adoption records reviewed did not
show documentation of the child’s updated adoption
assessment which was due in May 2022.
ADM 330 Quarterly progress reports
Quarterly progress reports (DHS-614) are to be
completed each quarter.
One of five open adoption records; and one of four
finalized adoption records reviewed (related to 14
adoption quarterlies reviewed) showed:
• One child’s 11/1/2022-1/30/2023 quarterly
progress report was completed 10 days late on
2/9/2023.
• A second child’s record did not show
documentation of an April 2022, July 2022, or
October 2022 quarterly progress report.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2022.
FOM 722-6B Family team meeting.
FTMs should include child welfare staff, parents,
caretakers, foster parents, children, youth, and may also
include extended family, friends, neighbors, community-
based service providers,
community representatives, tribal representatives, for
Indian children, or other professionals involved with the
family.
Each meeting must be documented in MiSACWIS using
the FTM hyperlink and all of the appropriate forms must
be completed for each type of meeting.
Certain circumstances, events, and/or stages of case
progression mandate FTMs must occur within the
required time frames as out lined in the following table.
Three of eight open child records reviewed did not show
compliance:
• One child’s record did not show
documentation of an FTM for the service
plan period 4/27/2022-7/25/2022: nor for

the period 10/23/2022-1/20/2023. One was
completed after the period on 1/30/2023.
• A second child’s record did not show
documentation of an FTM for the service
plan period 8/18/2022-11/11/2022.
• A third child’s record did not show
documentation of an FTM for the service
plan period 7/31/2022-10/28/2022; nor
10/29/2022-1/20/2023.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2022.
FOM 802-1 Medical Passport.
Updated Medical Passport:
All medical information within the medical passport
must be current and updated at least quarterly to
reflect the child's current and complete health
information.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Participating legal parents, if the child is
a temporary court ward; Quarterly, while
in out-of-home placement; and at
reunification.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed did not
show documentation of a June 2022 or December 2022
updated medical passport.
Repeat Violation, Interim 2022.

EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There was one substantiated incident of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
This incident related an allegaton that the foster parent beat a foster child with an
extension cord and the child had a scar on his face and eye. During the
investigation the foster parent admitted to grabbing a belt and whooping the child.
The foster parent reported becoming angry with the child after the child scared her
as it related to what she thought was an in home intruder. The foster parent
reported she was trying to hit the child’s buttock with the belt, and as a result of
the child moving to dodge the belt, she may have hit other body parts. The foster
parent was found in violation of the foster home applicant/licensee qualification
rule due to the corporal punishment. Due to this rule violation and departmental
actions, revocation of the foster home’s license was recommended.
The agency adhered to standards and time frames related to this special
evaluation.
There was one incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
This incident related to an allegation that a foster parent popped a youth in the
mouth for being disrespectful. During the investigation the foster parent admitted
to using her finger to pop the youth on the lip. The foster home was found in
violation of the behavior management rule. A corrective action plan was developed
with the foster home that included a safety plan signed by the foster parent related
to not using physical discipline.
The agency adhered to standards and time frames related to this special
evaluation.
The agency has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans during
this licensing period.
The first corrective plan related to the agency’s 2022 Interim Inspection, where the
agency received the following rule violations:
• R400.12212(2)(d) Personnel records.
• R400.12212(2)(h) Personnel records.
• 400.12306(4) Application request.
• R400.12324(8) Reevaluation.
• R400.12327(6)(c) Special evaluation.
• R400.12327(7) Special evaluation.
• R400.12405(5)(a)-(b) Change of placement.
• R400.12413(1) (c) (ii)Medical and dental policy.
• R400.12413(a)(f)(i) Medical and dental policy.
• R400.12418(2) (b) Development of service plans.

• R400.12419(1)(c) & (h) Initial service plans.
• R400.12605(1) Adoptive family evaluation.
• R400.12607(4) Agency recommendation.
• MISEP 6.16 Supervisory Oversight.
• ADM 330 Quarterly progress reports.
• ADM 980 Closing documentation.
• FOM 722-6B Family team meeting.
• FOM 722-6H Documentation of contacts.
• FOM 722-6H Case worker contact with child in out of home placement.
• FOM 722-8 Case Service Plans-Overview, and Timeframes-Supervisor
Approval.
• FOM 722-8D Treatment Plans- Agreement and Signature.
• FOM 722-8E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary.
• FOM 722-15 Discharge documents.
• FOM 801 Dental examination schedule.
• FOM 801-3 Medical passport.
• FOM 802-2 Mental and Behavioral health
The agency reported and demonstrated significant progress related to its Interim
Inspection’s corrective action plan. Proof of such was observed during the
employee and case file reviews. Additional, proof of the agency’s progress on this
corrective action plan was viewed on 4/4/2023. I reviewed documentation of
various checklists, procedure/policy highlighting licensing time frames,
spreadsheets, Book of Business Worker Calendar Reviews, samples of various
supervisory meetings, supervisor/worker meetings, and monthly file audits, as well
as, proof of various reported training, and PowerPoints related to topics on family
team meetings, medical passports, action summaries, etc., were observed related
to actions the agency implemented to achieve greater rule compliance.
With the exception of the agency not completing the task of making a secondary
contact/reminder to a caregiver at least two weeks prior to a child’s medical
examination due date; and the agency not completing three trainings (Action
Summary, Social Work contact Expectations, and Trauma Screening) by the
targeted 8/25/2022 completion date( the trainings were completed on 2/24/2023,
2/26/2023, and 2/23/2023 respectively); the agency completed the actions listed in
this corrective action plan.
The second corrective action plan related to Special Investigation 2022C040025
initiated 8//22/2022. The complaint alleged the agency was aware that two youths
in the foster home had incidents of sexually inappropriate behavior with one
another and failed to implement safety planning. The agency received a rule
violation for R400.12207(3)(a) for Staff responsibility; and submitted an acceptable
corrective action plan on 11/16/2022. On 4/4/2023, the agency provided
documentative proof of home visit discussions, home visit form revision; safety
plan review discussions; and case manager/ management team case
conferences, which were actions the agency indicated in the corrective action plan

that it would implement and complete. This corrective action plan has been
achieved.
Entrance/ Exit Conference:
The chief administrator, licensee designee, director, program manager, licensing
supervisor, adoption supervisor, foster care supervisors and various other staff
attended the entrance and exit conference. The entrance centered on a review
and of the agency’s staffing, current challenges if any, program changes/status/
functioning; and policy changes, if any. The Department of Child Welfare
Licensing (DCWL) Analyst attended the first portion of the entrance conference via
TEAMS; and presented her findings from the unlicensed relatives and foster home
visits.
The exit conference, focused on a summary of staff interviews, the results of the
Renewal Inspection/ indicated rule and policy violations, and a discussion of the
agency’s last inspection’s corrective action plan. One foster care worker, one
adoption worker, one licensing workers, one independent living worker, two
supervisors, two adoptive families and two independent living youths were
interviewed during this inspection.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator’s report dated 3/25/2023 was received and reviewed. The
agency assessed its areas of noncompliance indicated in the 2022 Interim
Inspection. The agency completed all aspects as required by that chief
administrator’s document.
Financial Overview
The agency provided an annual budget and annual financial audit. No concerns
were noted.
Staff and Youth Interviews
No major concerns were reported by staff interviewed.
A concern came out of youth interviews. A desire was expressed to have a
courtesy notification from the agency when the youth’s assigned case worker
resigns/leaves; so that the youth knows and is not finding out much later. This
information was shared with the agency.
Description of Agency Walk Through
There were no concerns observed.
VI. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There was one safety alert this inspection.
Concern:
The smoke detector in the hallway between the bedrooms is missing. The foster
parent does not have a smoke detector in the kitchen. There is no carbon monoxide
detector in the home.

Resolution:
The agency’s licensing supervisor conducted a foster home visit on 2/23/2023 and
observed appropriate devices in place in the home. A carbon monoxide detector
was in the garage near the furnace and water heater. A combination smoke/carbon
monoxide detector was in the kitchen; a smoke detector was in the hallway by the
bedrooms, and smoke detectors were in each bedroom. The agency provided
photos showing the devices in place.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
_____________________________________
Lonia Perry Calloway Date April 10, 2023
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
April 11, 2023
_____________________________________
Linda D Tansil Date
Area Manager
